description: search for superproductivity
Does what it's supposed to do. Launches fine from the application menu as well as directly from the search bar.
Search for "Timer" in the Unity dashboard and it comes up!
beautiful,i love it.
Great, only need a taskbar icon so I can close the app

Decent Pomodoro application, but with some annoyances. 

Even after telling it to stay in the background, using the application's settings, the application lays it self on top of all other applications.

Also beware that the application defaults to reading out notifications out loud, such as when you are nearing the end of a work interval, through your speakers. If you do not want that, you must either disable it in the settings (and restart the application), wear headphones, or simply mute all sound.
Sometimes it bugs and it's in the middle of the screen and I can't remove it. If not for this bug I would give it a 5 star.
summary: Great but doesn't it doesn't always work

description: Amazing pomodor timer. I had no problems launching the app. I think the developer fixed the launch bug.

I was unable to launch it, however there's no way to turn off the creepy robot voice that commands you to stop working after the 25 minutes, also it crashes after the first 25 minutes, leaving a white square in the foreground of the screen that steals your context whenever you try to type in any other window. Worse than useless

When you are on the break the screen is blank, you dont how much you have left and cannot stop it from counting.

also you cannot reset the number of the session, lets say you are in session 2 but wanna restart the sessions from the first one

MOST importantly for me, is to have a mini view of it, where you can keep it on screen, so that you can see all the time how much time you got left, just like the pomodoro technique says, but so that it doesn't occupy so much screen space.

Something positive, is that in the beggining i was kinda surprised when I heard the narrator speak, but then I got used to it and liked it. It would be cool to be able to customize the narrated text.
summary: Beautiful, but missing some functionality, a bit buggy

description: I like the way if continues to acquire cursor focus to force you to obey. Unfortunately I use ctrl-r to search my terminal command history a ton, so I have to uninstall this:(
It is not working.

This software looked really good, design is really satisfying. However, I understood why people rated so low on this software after using it.
It's the lack of preferences. When there's a break, program always stays on top and you have no choice to disable it.
Developer should extend the features of the app.
This application's window comes to the foreground regardless of whether the setting is enabled. It is also hard to kill. Very annoying.
I can't start session when I need, it starts by itself. Application always on top, I don't need this

I've been using this timer, and I've been able to reproduce the same faulty behavior: For a 25 min working session, the real count is 35 min. 
Also, I don't enjoy the way it looks the apps during a break, and that I can't minimize it so I can watch a funny video or something to relax.
This app runs perfectly under Ubuntu 20.04. I Really love the design and simplicity of the timer, and of course, it does what it's supposed to do. Recommended!

I liked it. It plays a voice sound advising you to prepare to rest or to start working. In that way you can forget about the program running in the background.

The only thing it miss is an applet (icon in the dashboard)
summary: It blocks somehow your computer. I love it

description: The application looks amazing, works fine in my setup BUT DANG THIS ROBOT VOICE IS ANNOYING.
summary: Works fine but annoying notification voice

description: it is very good

I found 4 ways of launching this:

1. After installing it from Software, still on its page in Software, I simply clicked on "Launch", and it launched. (I then added it to my favourites, just in case, but I didn't need to.)
2. In "show applications" it was there as "Productivity Timer"
3. Open a terminal (Ctr+Alt+t), type "productivity-timer" (no quotes) and press enter;
4. In Gno-Menu, start typing "productivity timer"

So if there was a problem it appears to have been fixed.
It is quickly developed. works well for me.
Menu item was present (Xubuntu)

I googled and found the command to install it.

sudo snap install productivity-timer --candidate

That gives you the name!
This works as described
spikes cpu usage
I can run it. It is beatiful. Helpful for me..

App worked first time (I'm running Ubuntu 19.10), didn't misbehave. So as a Pomodoro timer, it does provide that function. 

The end of a work session, or of a break, is pre-announced and then announced by a synthetic voice and a notification sound. I quite like the notification sound, I *hated* the voice. But there's no way to lose the synth voice without turning off all notifications.

Decent attempt, but I uninstalled it.
